description:
Paenibacillus larvae subsp. larvae is a Gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium that is the causative agent of American Foulbrood (AFB), a severe and highly contagious disease affecting honeybee (Apis spp.) larvae. This subspecies is the primary causative agent of AFB, a devastating infection that can devastate entire honeybee colonies if left untreated.

The bacterium is characterized by its ability to produce highly resistant endospores that can survive in the environment for extended periods, even years. Upon ingestion by honeybee larvae, the spores germinate and the vegetative cells proliferate rapidly, eventually leading to the death of the infected larvae. The disease is primarily transmitted through the exchange of contaminated materials, such as beekeeping equipment, honey, or the movement of infected colonies.

Paenibacillus larvae subsp. larvae is considered a significant threat to apiculture, as it can cause substantial economic losses and threaten the health and survival of honeybee populations, which are crucial pollinators for many agricultural crops. Effective management of this bacterium requires early detection, proper disinfection of equipment, and the implementation of appropriate treatment strategies by beekeepers.
